Row.Text: Devastatingly powerful Renaissance Era siege unit. Only the Mughals may build it. Must set up prior to firing. Vulnerable to melee attacks, and cannot move while damaged.

The Farsakh Cannon is the Mughal unique unit, replacing the Cannon. Like the Cannon it has limited visibility and must set up (1 mp) to attack. Although extremely expensive, Farsakh Cannons have incredibly high Ranged Combat strength. They are vulnerable to melee attacks and become immobile while damaged. Keep them well protected and they will be an invaluable asset on the field.

Other than founding the Mughal Empire, one of Babur's many achievements was the introduction of artillery on a large scale into India early in the 16th century. As the first battle of Panipat in 1526 has shown, massed cannon fire proved to be both terrifying and decisive. From that point on, the Mughals have become the unquestionable masters of artillery in the Subcontinent. Farsakh Cannons were the embodiment of Mughal pursuit of the best and most beautiful guns in the world. These enormous pieces of ordnance were capable of firing 50-pound (23 kilogram) lead balls at a distance of one farsakh - roughly 4 miles, or 6 kilometres. The cannons were regarded as pieces of art, lavishly decorated with gold ornaments and inscriptions, and were even given names. However, despite all the potency and beauty of these weapons, moving them into position was slow and arduous and required dozens of oxen or even elephants to pull them around.
Cheaper and weaker Musketman replacement. Only the Maratha may build it.
The Sepoy is a Marathi unique unit, replacing the Musketman. Although less powerful than the Musketman, it is also less expensive, allowing them to be produced more quickly and in greater numbers.

Sepoy (from Persian "sipahi" meaning "soldier") was a general term given to native Indian infantrymen within the armies of the Maratha, the Mughals and the kingdom of Mysore. Sepoy regiments were usually armed with matchlock muskets, rockets and grenades, in a fashion slightly akin to European-style line infantry of the 18th century - even though they lacked the uniformity of the armies of the West. European colonial companies in India also employed sepoys as their main fighting force in the area. Those soldiers would continue their service well into the 19th century, and some regiments within the British Army fought in France during World War 1. Later, sepoys would provide a base on which modern Indian army was built after the Subcontinent regained its independence. Famous sepoy military formations still exist - like the Maratha Light Infantry regiment, formed in 1768 and active to this day.
Lancer replacement with bonuses against Gunpowder units. Only the Maratha may build it.

The Pindari are a Marathi unique unit, replacing Lancers. In addition to the normal bonuses received by Lancers, Pindari also get bonuses against Gunpowder units, making them significantly more useful.

The Pindari, also known as the Free Companions, were bands of warriors and horsemen from various Indian tribes, whose main purpose was to raid and plunder enemy territory. They emerged as a potent military force during the 18th century, at the time of decline of the Mughal Empire. Loosely organized and commanded by self-chosen leaders, the Pindaris often found themselves under the patronage of wealthy Maratha dynasties. They would prove their mettle when the Maratha clashed with the British East India Company in early 19th century. Up to 30.000 horsemen would gather every year in November and ride off to ravage British-held territory. A retaliatory campaign was mounted by the British in 1817, which would soon escalate into open war. This conflict, known as the Third Anglo-Maratha War, would end not only the Pindari, but also the Maratha Empire itself.
Stronger and more expensive than the Great War Infantry, which it replaces. Receives a bonus when fighting outside friendly territory

The Gurkha is an elite Infantry unit unique to India. Although it is more expensive than the Great War Infantry, the Gurkha is stronger, and recieves a bonus when fighting outside of friendly territory.

The Gurkhas are a people native to mountainous Nepal and Gorkhaland region of India. Famed for their bravery, fearlessness and disregard for death, they impressed British military commanders as early as in 1814, during the Gurkha War waged by the East India Company against Nepal. In 1815, even before the war ended, the first regiment of Gurkhas was formed within the British Indian army. Throughout 19th and well into the 20th century, the Gurkhas remained loyal to the British crown, despite wars and numerous Indian rebellions. They fought in both World Wars as a part of the British Army, where they formed fifteen rifle regiments. They were widely admired for their ability to withstand any hardship and feared of their skill with the deadly khukuri knife. Gurkha regiments remain in service to this day.
Unique Chola Great Admiral capable of fighting alongside your other Naval units. Becomes more powerful as you gain more advanced Technology.

The Thalai-Thirvai is a unique Great Admiral replacement. Unlike the standard Great Admiral, the Thalai-Thirvai is a combat unit; capable of fighting alongside your other Naval units. The Thalai-Thirvai will become more powerful as you gain more advanced Technology.

Admirals of the Chola Navy held many ranks within its highly organized administration. One of the most important offices was the Thalai (head) Thirvai (duty), the overseer of the customs department which was mainly responsible for trade and tariffs. This unit of Chola bureaucracy employed only the best merchants and professional economists of the empire, tasked with calculating duties and other financial obligations of trade partners. They also assessed the prices of commodities, depending on seasons and trade route length. Other arms of Chola customs force included intelligence corps, armed naval vessels tasked with police duties, a coast guard and even privateer squads
Only the Chola may build this unit. It receives extra [ICON_STRENGTH] Combat Strength adjacent to Barbarian units.
The Kadatpadai is the Chola Caravel replacement. It receives extra [ICON_STRENGTH] Combat Strength adjacent to Barbarian units; ensuring safe travel in foreign seas.

Kadatpadai is a collective term for the entirety of Chola navy. While it was of great importance to the Cholas from the very beginning, it had to wait until the empire's rejuvenation in 9th century AD, when the fleet's true potential was discovered, and the number of ships greatly increased. Vital to commerce and expansion, Chola navy was employed in a variety of roles - from protecting trade routes and performing diplomatic missions up to combatting rampant Sri Vijaya piracy and securing the empire's interests via force and intimidation, in a fashion not unlike that of „gunboat diplomacy”. Upon contact with the Chinese in 11th century along came cooperation – the fleet enjoyed new ship designs, mixing Indian and Chinese elements to provide the navy with highly specialized vessels. As the empire's splendour grew, so did the position of Chola Admirals, who became highly esteemed members of the society.

Set.Text: A fast Ranged Unit highly effective on flat ground. Only Maurya may build it. This Unit has a higher [ICON_STRENGTH] Combat and Ranged Strength than the Chariot Archer, which it replaces.

Converts 75% of the city's population to your religion. Eliminates all [ICON_HAPPINESS_3] Unhappiness from occupied cities

During and after his many conquests, the Mauryan king Ashoka ordered the construction of numerous stone pillars across India. Those columns were between 12 to 15 metres high (40 to 50 feet) and were adorned with animal capitals, mostly with images of stylised lions. Also, the pillars were carved with inscriptions bearing the Edicts of Ashoka. The Edicts were the king's view of Dhamma, a set of social and religious rules, guidelines and policies. 3rd century BC brought the emergence of Buddhism, common use of iron and migration of rural populace into cities – those and more events thoroughly transformed Indian society. Ashoka's edicts, based on Buddhist thought, were aimed at providing solutions to growing internal problems, as well as at documenting the spread of Buddhism – both in India and beyond.

Unlike the Courthouse which it replaces, the Pillars of Ashoka can be built in any city. It costs less maintenance and provides [ICON_PEACE] Faith, and will also convert 75% of the city's population to your Religion. Use it to strengthen and spread your Religion throughout the empire. Only the Maurya may build it.
+1 [ICON_PEACE] Faith for every 2 [ICON_CITIZEN] Citizen in the city

A Mandir is a Hinduist or Jainist temple. The word comes from the Sanskrit ‘mandira', which means ‘house', ‘palace' or ‘temple'. Hundreds of mandirs are spread throughout India and Southeast Asia, where they are called Candi or Wat, amongst other names. A single mandir is often dedicated to a single deity. A brightly decorated altar of the god or goddess is the centre of the temple, where people come to worship and meditate. In some religious complexes there are many individual shrines placed over a larger area, forming one mandir; in others multiple shrines are part of one building. Such temples would often be accompanied by a well or pool of water, where ritual bathing takes place, required before any prayer. One of the most famous and largest mandirs is the Prambanan temple in Indonesia, made of stone in 9th century AD.

In addition to the +2 [ICON_PEACE] Faith provided by the Temple which it replaces, the Mandir also provides +1 [ICON_PEACE] Faith for every 2 [ICON_CITIZEN] Citizens in the city. This building will be extremely useful in accumulating [ICON_PEACE] Faith through the ages, especially in tall empires. Only India may build it

Set.Text: The Qila is a Medieval-era building. It is the Indian unique building, replacing the Castle. The Qila improves the city's Defensive strength and provides some [ICON_CULTURE] Culture every turn. After Flight is learned, it provides a [ICON_GOLD] Gold bonus to the city as well. Building Walls is a prerequisite for building the Qila.

Provides +2 [ICON_TOURISM] Tourism after Flight is researched.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Provides +1 [ICON_GOLDEN_AGE] Golden Age point for every two wonders and 1 for every four buildings in the city. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Contains one slot for a Great Work of Art. City must have Walls.

Row.Text: May the blessings of god be upon you, O great Akbar, Emperor of the Mughal Empire! You are the bloodline of Timur, oh he of whom tales of glory are known and songs are sung the world over! You live up to and exceed the reputation of your forefathers, for it was under your rule that the Mughal Empire extended its borders far beyond that which it had yet achieved, bringing the majority of the Indian subcontinent under your rule through a series of devastating military campaigns in which you were undefeated, using weapons at the forefront of technological achievement. Truly did you earn the epithet "the Great"! [NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Yet the achievements of the Mughals were not limited to the field of battle. Your people were innovators, building engineering marvels the likes of which the world had never seen: impregnable fortresses, monuments to love, and temples of science. These wonders of architecture lasted long after the fall of the empire, and have remained testament to the ability and legacy of the Mughal Empire for centuries, remaining unchanged while the land around them passed through the control of several powers – each reminded of the achievements of you, oh Emperor![NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Akbar! The people of India cry out to you! They yearn for your leadership to usher them into a new golden age! Will you answer their call and take to the field of battle once more? Can you restore the Mughal Empire to her former glory? Can you build a civilization that can stand the test of time?

Mighty Shivaji Bhosale, the Maratha Empire awaits your command! Under your leadership the Maratha Empire was founded, growing from an enclave of the Sultanate of Bijapur to a powerful state that would successfully challenge the famed Mughal Empire; ending its era of supremacy over India. This empire would remain the pre-eminent power in India for centuries to come. King Shivaji, your innovative military tactics allowed the fledgling empire you founded to successfully triumph over greater foes. This, in concert with your actions to reinstate ancient Hindu political traditions and court conventionsm as well as ending the use of the foreign Persian language in court, have earned you an honoured place in the annals of Indian history.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj! Your armies stand ready for you to lead them. Will the Maratha Empire once again dominate under your firm guidance? Will your people once again prosper? Can you build a civilization to stand the test of time?

All hail Raja Raja of the Chola Dynasty! May your empire ever prosper! Raja Raja, your nation was a great one; stretching from the Tungabhadra River downwards to the Indian Ocean. Her Kings were great patrons of Tamil culture, resulting in many temples and works of literature which stand testament to the empire's grandeur. The Chola Navy was a true wonder, having grown from a small backwater entity to that of a potent power projection and diplomatic symbol in all of Asia. Raja Raja! Your leadership saw your empire expand and grow; it saw your armies and navies dominate India. Your military campaigns brought the nations around you under your command.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Mighty Emperor! The time has come for you to return the Chola Empire to greatness. Your armies and navies stand ready. Will you take charge and lead them to glory? Will you build a civilization to stand the test of time?

May you be blessed with peace and happiness Great Ashoka of the Maurya Dynasty! O Ashoka; at your feet lies the mighty Mauryan Empire; the largest nation of its age. After its foundation in 322 BC, the empire rapidly expanded; crushing the Satraps of Alexander's Empire. The fledging nation continued to grow, eventually encompassing nearly the entirety of the Indian Subcontinent. Ashoka, Emperor of Emperors, under your rule your empire waged bloody wars against neighbouring lands, bringing them under Mauryan rule. In the wake of these wars, you saw the pain your actions had caused and converted to Buddhism in repentance; spreading the religion throughout Asia and beyond, and cementing your place in history as one of the greatest monarchs the world has ever seen.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Samraat Chakravartin Ashoka! Shall you once again lead your empire to expand and grow? Will you once again bring the petty nations around you under your wise guidance? Will you build a Civilization to stand the test of time?
During [ICON_GOLDEN_AGE] Golden Ages every 2 Buildings provide +1 [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production and Wonders provide +3 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture.

Domestic Trade routes yield +1 [ICON_GOLD] Gold. Trade Routes with City-States generate Great Admiral points and influence with the City-State (this does not suspend influence decay). Bonuses doubled for Naval trade routes.

Row.Text: The Mughal Empire was a Persianate empire that grew to rule very nearly the entire Indian subcontinent at its peak, stretching from Bengal in the east to Kabul in the west, from Kashmir in the north to Kaveri in the south. The emperors of the Mughal came from Uzbekistan, claiming descendancy from both Genghis Khan and Timur; two of the world's most successful and well known warlords. The Mughals brought about Persian culture and architecture into medieval India, the golden age of the empire saw the creation of many buildings with the Persian and Mughal influences; most notable are the Taj Mahal and Moti Masjid in Agra.

At its peak the Mughals controlled most of the subcontinent and parts of neighboring Nepal and Afghanistan. Much of the Indian terrain is a flat plain with tropical and sub-tropical regions covering much of the plain and the base of the mountain ranges.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The north of the subcontinent is quite different; jagged and mountainous. The Himalayas that border Asia from the subcontinent have souring mountains so high that the region is often called the 'Roof of the World'. The west of the empire is a hilly desert with sparse plant life and few sources of water.

At the young age of 12 Zahir ud-din Muhammad Babur spent much of his life in exile and without shelter from his uncles, they have made continuous attempts to dislodge him as the ruler of Farghana. In 1497 Babur saw a great deal of bad luck while besieging Samarkand, despite his capturing of the city a rebellion between the nobles stole Farghana from his control. Then as Babur marched to return and reclaim the land his troops deserted in Samarkand, leaving him with no land to rule over. Four years later he again attempted the conquest of Sarmarkand, this time failing in the battle against the Khan of the Uzbeks - Muhammad Shaybani. For three years after Babur and his band of followers sought to build a strong army, recruiting amongst others mostly the Tajiks of Badakhshan. By 1504 he crossed the Hindu Kush mountains and captured Kabul, doing so earned him a new kingdom to settle into and a re-establishment of his fortunes and the title of Padshah; the next year saw him reunite with a Timurid relative and scheme with him to fight against the Uzbek Khan, but the death of the relative delayed the undertaking and the diminishing resources caused Babur to leave Herat.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]A rebellion erupted in Kabul causing Babur to return and quash the uprising, but after just two years another revolt among his generals drove him out of Kabul with dwindling companions. Babur returned to reclaim Kabul and regaining the allegiance of the rebels. During this, in 1510, Babur's bitter rival Muhammad Shaybani fell in combat against Shah Ismail I of Shia Safavid Persia; upon hearing this Babur used this to strike a partnership with Ismail and reconquer his former lands.

The partnership was solid but the conquest proved ineffective; writing in retrospect Babur suggested his failing to capture Samarkand was the greatest gift Allah gave to him, Babur also resigned all hope of recovering Farghana. While fearing an invasion from the Uzbeks he drew his attention to the east, especially to the rich land of the Delhi Sultanate of India. Claiming to be the true monarch of the lands of the Lodi dynasty Babur believed he was the rightful heir to the throne of Timur. The reigning sultan Ibrahim Lodi ousted the Sayyid dynasty, a dynasty with an indirect link to Timur, Babur sought to restore it to the Timurids. While in no rush to launch a full scale invasion Babur made several incursions against the Lodi and seized Kandahar in the process, the occupation however lasted nearly three years as the city and its citadel were taken.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Babur's allies advised him to ally with the powerful Janjua Rajputs to join his conquest. The Janjua were known for their rebellion against the throne of Delhi and their support of Timur during his conquests. Babur aided the Janjua against their enemy and gained their alliance against the Lodi. The First Battle of Panipat saw the victory of Babur in destroying the Lodi dynasty and from that founded a new dynasty in the region, the Mughal dynasty.

Babur's son Humayun became the next Mughal ruler in 1530 but suffered many reversals at the hand of Sher Shah Suri of the Pashtun, losing most of the territory won by his father in India. Humayun crossed the Makran region with his wife to the fortress in Umarkot in Sind to bare their son. From 1540 Humayun became a ruler in exile, reaching the court of the Safavid rule by 1544. Between 1553 and 1556 the Hindu king Hemu Vikramaditya claimed the Delhi throne by defeating the Mughals in both Agra and Delhi. Humayun recaptured the throne but in January 1556 he slipped from the Din Panah building and died. The Mughals would re-establish their foundations in Delhi from Humayun's son, Akbar.

Akbar became the Mughal ruler in 1556, he was a wise ruler; while high he set reasonable taxes to the population - one-fifth of their agricultural production, he was more inclusive to the non-Muslim citizens of the empire, he allied with the Rajputs for his conquests, he appointed natives as generals and administrators, he even created a form of syncretic philosophy based on tolerance.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]While Akbar's son, Jahangir's rule of the empire was largely uneventful Jahangir's son, Shah Jahan would ascend to the throne in October 1627. Shah Jahan commissioned the construction of many famous buildings in the empire, the most famous being the Taj Mahal as a tomb for his wife Mumtaz Mahal who died giving birth to their fourteenth child.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The day before August 1658 Aurangzeb Alamgir, one of Shah Jahan's sons, ascended to the Mughal throne. By 1690 Aurangzeb drove the Mughal Empire to its zenith in territorial claim.

Undoubtedly the biggest Mughal contribution to India is the unique architecture, the Taj Mahal is often depicted as one of the finest examples of Mughal architecture. While recalling the structures of central Asia Babur and his descendants infused the native Indian style into the building of their monuments, forts and palaces. Other forms of Mughal influence are found in the governments of the neighboring kingdoms, the Persian art and culture infused into artworks and literature, new trade routes to the Arab and Turkic lands, Mughal cuisine and the unique landscape gardening found in the many buildings built by the Mughals.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]As the Mughals slowly unified the subcontinent the economy flourished as old kingdoms became joined by new road systems and a uniform currency was established. Manufactured goods were sold around the world, the key industries being shipbuilding, textiles and steel. The Mughal fleet was small as it merely served to send pilgrims to Mecca and import Arab horses in Surat. While cities boomed during Mughal rule they were mostly military and political centers and only guilds that produces goods for the bureaucracy made goods in towns; the remainder of the industry based in rural areas. The Bengal region was especially prosperous under Mughal rule.

The decline of the Mughals began as Chatrapati Shivaji , leader of the Maratha Empire declared independence for Hindus and began to raise an army. Santaji Ghorpade and Dhanaji Jadhav, two of the Maratha's best warriors eliminated most of the Mughal generals one by one. Aurangzeb engaged the Mughals into the War of 27 Years against the Marathas where the Mughals suffered heavy loses and defeats. By 1706 Aurangzeb's son Prince Bakht was routed by Dhanaji, bringing additional disgrace to the throne, Aurangzeb's death only a few months after would display the dire situation of the Mughal status. The Maratha Peshwa ravaged Mughal outposts after Aurangzeb's death. Shivaji's son Shahu was released by the Mughals in an effort to establish peace between the two empires, but this failed as Peshwa Vishwanath Balaji Rao continued to expand the Maratha empire. Vishwanath's son, Baji Rao I overthrew the Mughals from Deccan to the Punjab and from Bengal to Sindh. Baji Rao I continued to invade northern Mughal territories in 1728 with none of the Muslim generals able to stop him; by 1737 Baji Rao I invaded and captured Delhi itself. The war resulted in the near complete destruction of the Mughal Empire single-handedly.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The last of the Mughals ruled only over Delhi for the next century when Emperor Bahadur Shah II supported the Indian Rebellion of 1857. In a twist of irony he was overthrown by the British, his sons killed and the last of the empire was absorbed into the British Raj.
[NEWLINE] Leader: Akbar[NEWLINE] Unique Unit: Farsakh Cannon[NEWLINE] Unique Building: Qila[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]

The name 'Mughal' is derived from the original homeland of the Timurids - 'Moghulistan', meaning 'Land of Mongols'.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The Mughals made advances in observational astronomy, Humayun himself built his own personal observatory near Delhi. The most notable creation of Mughal India is the seamless celestial globe.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Fathullah Shirazi, the Persian polymath and mechanical engineer who worked for Akbar developed the volley gun.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]During the Siege of Bidar in 1657 the forces of then Prince Aurangzeb utilized fired rockets and grenades as they scaled the walls. Sidi Marjan was mortally wounded after a rocket struck the gunpowder deposit.

The Maratha Confederacy was an imperial power of India during the late seventeenth to early nineteenth century made famous by its conquest of the Mughal Empire. Founded by Shivaji Bhosle, the Marathas began as a yeoman warrior group of western Deccan; they fought in the longest war in Indian history to ultimately defeat the Mughals and rule the Indian subcontinent. The Marathas gained a command of the seas as most of the border was coastline and kept the European navies at bay.

At the height of their power, the Marathas controlled most of the subcontinent, much of the Indian terrain is a flat plain with tropical and sub-tropical regions covering much of the plain and the base of the mountain ranges. The subcontinent is flanked by two massive rivers, the Indus and Ganges; each river contains a large array of sister rivers branching off into the heart of the land and large deltas at the mouths of the rivers, creating vast areas of wetlands at the easterly and westerly points of the landmass.

Shivaji was an aristocrat of the Bhosle clan who founded the Maratha empire, he led a resistance to free the Marathas from the Sultanate of Bijapur and re-establish 'Hindavi Swarajya' - the self rule of Hindu people, for a more detailed look into Shivaji and his war against the Mughals see his Civilopedia entry. Shivaji established Raigad as the capital of the new empire and successfully defended Maratha from the Mughals, he was crowned Chhatrapati, or 'sovereign', of the Maratha empire in 1674. His elder son Sambhaji was very popular among the courtiers and in 1681 he was crowned emperor and resumed his father's expansion. Sambhaji saw early victories against the Portuguese and Chikka Deva Raya of Mysore while the Mughal emperor Aurangzeb moved south to conquer the Marathas and neighboring sultanates. In the eight years of war that followed Sambhaji never lost a battle nor fort to Aurangzeb save for one during early 1689; Aurangzeb ambushed Sangamshwar and captured Sambhaji and his adviser where they were executed on March 11 of that year.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]At the death of his older brother Rajaram took the throne. As the Mughals laid siege on Raigad he fled to Vishalgad and then Ginge for safety. From there the Marathas raided Mughal territory, claiming many forts and gaining a great deal of ground. Rajaram offered a truce in 1697 but the Mughals rejected it, three years later Rajaram died in Sinhagad. His widow Tarabai held the throne in the name of her son Ramaraja, she led the Marathas heroically and by 1705 they crossed the Narmada River, entering Malwa. The conquest of Malwa proved decisive for the Maratha Empire as the Mughals lost their grip on the subcontinent, resulting in the emperors reduced to titular rulers. The victory set the foundations of the imperial conquests of later expansions under the Peshwas.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]However, after Aurangzeb's death in 1707, Sambhaji's son Shahuji was released by the next Mughal - Bahadur Shah I, under the conditions that rendered him a vassal of the Mughal emperor. Shahuji claimed the throne and challenged his aunt Tarabai and her son, this caused a split in the states over the succession dispute; the states of Satara and Kolhapur formed in 1707 and three years later the two principalities became established fact. Furrukhsiyar became Mughal emperor in 1713 and his bid for power depended heavily on the Saiyid brothers, who at the time had a falling-out with the emperor. Negotiations with the Saiyids and Peshwa Belaji Vishwanath, a civilian representative of Shahuji, drew the Marathas into the Saiyids vendetta. The next year saw a Maratha army march to Delhi unopposed, deposing the Mughal emperor. In return for the help Vishwanath negotiated a substantial treaty; Shahuji would accept Mughal control in the Deccan, furnish forces for the imperial army and pay annual tribute, in return Shahuji received an imperial directive guaranteeing Swaraj, 'independence' in the Maratha homeland and the rights to chauth and sardeshmukh, a form of tax, throughout Gujarat, Malwa and the six provinces of the Mughal Deccan, amounting to 35% of the total revenue. The treaty also released Shahuji's mother Yesubai from the Mughals. During this time the Marathas pushed the borders of the empire in all directions, the houses of the victorious generals would ultimately undermine the king's authority and bring the rule of the Bhosle clan to a close.

After Vishwanath's death in April 1720 his son Baji Rao Vishwanath Bhatt was appointed Peshwa, the equivalent of a Prime Minister, by Chattrapati Shahu. Shahu was able to see talent in his people, and doing so caused a social revolution by bringing capable people into power regardless of their status or upbringing. This led to a great social mobility within the empire and enabled a rapid expansion. While Peshwa Baji Rao I was a great general who never lost a battle in his campaigns - 41 battles, 41 victories. He is also credited with expanding the frontiers, especially the north. His expansion included the Battle of Palkhed on February 28, 1728 against Nizm-ul-Mulk of Hyperbad, the battle is an example of superior military strategy at work. Another victory and a major achievement for Baji Rao I was the Battle of Vasai, fought between the empire and Portuguese-owned Vasai the Marathas were led by one of Baji Rao's brothers Chimaji Appa.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Baji Rao's son Balaji Baji Rao was appointed Peshwa after his father's death on April 25 1740, almost immediately he launched an invasion of both Damalcheery and Arcot, both falling in quick succession. Balaji then invaded Trichinopoly in December that year, unable to resist the attack Chanda Saheb past the fort to the Maratha general Raghuji on March 14, 1741; Saheb was arrested and sent to Nagpur. The next four years of his rule was of general calm in the Deccan, while Rughuji would continue to harass and annex kingdom after kingdom in six campaigns in the Bengal from 1741 to 1748. Chattrapati Shahuji died in 1749 and moved power of the state to the Peshwa under the condition that the house of Shivaji will be maintained and the welfare of its subjects were tended to. The Nawab of Bengal, Alivardi Khan brokered peace with Rughaji in 1751 ceding land and annual tribute of 1,200,000 rupees while the smaller states of Raipur, Ratanpur, Bilaspur and Sambalpur were conquered and placed in charge of an illegitimate son of the general. By the end of his career Rughaji conquered Berar, the Gond kingdoms of Devgad, Nagpur, Gadha-Mandla and Chandrapur, the Suba of Cuttack and smaller states between Nagpur and Cuttack. Balaji Baji Rao encouraged agriculture, protected the villagers and brought about improvement in the state of the empire. Continuing expansion saw the empire reach Delhi as the Afghan withdrew after Ahmed Shah Abdali's plunder of the city; Balaji's brother, Raghuath Rao captured Delhi in August 1757, laying the corner-stone of Maratha influence in northwestern India. The empire was now a major player on the subcontinent.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]On May 8, 1758 the Marathas took Peshawar from the Afghans; the general Sadashiv Rao Bhau, upon hearing about the Afghans' return to North India, promptly marched to recapture Delhi. The formal Mughal capital and then Afghan garrison fell once again to the Marathas in August 1760; Delhi was already in a poor state due to the constant destruction of the city and depopulation from the countless battles and endless war that buy this time acute supply shortages affected the Maratha camp, still Bhau once again ordered its sacking, he also planned to install his nephew Vishwars Rao on the Mughal throne. By 1760, after the victory over the Nizam in the Deccan, the empire reached its zenith - controlling 2,800,000 square kilometer acres. The Afghan Emir Ahmad Shah Durrani called upon allies to drive out the 'infidels' from Delhi, massive Muslim forces clashed with the Hindus on January 14, 1761 where the Marathas lost and for the first time halted their expansion. Antagonized by heavy taxes the Jats and Rajputs resided their support for the Marathas, Raja Suraj Mal of Bharatput abandoned the empire and the Rajputs broke off their alliance at Agra before the Third Battle of Panipat. By 1771, in a bid to rebuild and stabilize the fractured empire Peshwa Madhav Rao I gave semi-autonomy to the strongest of the knights and in turn created a confederacy of states.

Thirteen knights of the former empire established their states across the breadth of the subcontinent, six states formed in the outer region of the empire and seven formed in the Maharashtra - the Maratha homelands. Mahadaji Shinde ruled the state of Gwalior in central India, he was instrumental in restoring Maratha power after the Third Battle of Panipat and became a trusted lieutenant of the Peshwa. Mahadaji also took complete advantage of Britain's neutrality to reaffirm Maratha power in northern India and was helped by French adventurer Benoît de Boigne in increasing his forces. Mahadaji launched his army to conquer the states who refused to pay tributes to him; in early 1771 he recaptured Delhi and installed Shah Alam II as a puppet on the Mughal throne - Shah Alam earned the title Vakil-ul-Mutlak, meaning 'vice-regent', of the empire. In the years that followed Mahadaji claimed the states of Bhopal, Datiya, Chanderi, Narwar, Salbai and Gohad; he attempted to take Jaipur but withdrew from the Battle of Lalsot in 1787 as it was inconclusive. Between the March months of 1786 and 1787 the Marathas fought Tipu Sultan where their emerged victorious. Delhi was briefly lost in 1788 to a Mughal noble Ismail Beg, he and his Rohilla ally, Ghulam Kadir captured the city and deposed and then blinded Shah Alam II. On October 2 of that year Mahadaji reclaimed the city and reinstalled Alam before sending Benoît de Boigne to destroy the forces of Jaipur and Marwar in two separate battles in 1790. Two years later Mahadaji made peace with Tipu and using his influence prevented a treaty between the British, the Nizam and the Peshwa against Tipu.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]After the Battle of Poona, the Peshwa left the government of the state to Yashwant Rao Holkar; he appointed Amrut Rao as the Peshwa and went to Indore on March 13, 1803. Besides the Gaikwad chief of Baroda, having accepted British protection nearly a year before, supported the new Peshwa. His battles were the most remarkable in India's history and the acclaim from the Mughal emperor gave him prominence amongst the rulers of India. As a clever organizer and skillful general Yashwant Rao tried to once again reunite the Confederacy; his armies were laid on sound military basis and his personality certainly preceded him as even in periods of instability, no state or power would consider any act of aggression on his state, the state of Holkar then was secure even after a number of years after his death.

During the Confederacy the British East India Company intervened in a succession battle in Pune, vouching for Raghunath Rao in 1775. From this came the First Anglo-Maratha War; it ended in 1782, restoring the status quo of before the conflict. In 1802 the British again intervened another conflict in Baroda to support the heir to the throne, the British signed a treaty with the new Maharaja recognizing his independence from the Maratha Empire in exchange for acknowledging British paramountcy. The Second Anglo-Maratha War sprang from Peshwa Baji Rao II and his defeat at the Battle of Poona against Yashwant Rao Holkar, he fled to British protection and in December 1802 signed a treaty with the British East India Company to cede territory for maintenance for an army and agreeing to treaty with noone else. The Maratha chieftains were horrified at the action and contested the agreement, sparking the conflict; as mentioned before Yashwant Rao sues for a treaty with the British in 1805, suspending the two year battle.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The Third Anglo-Maratha War was a last ditch effort to unite the states and regain sovereignty. The gamble did not pay off; most of the Maratha state came under British control and the Peshwa was exiled to Bithoor as a pensioner, the Maratha homelands came under direct British rule except Kolhapur and Satara. Gwalior, Indore and Nagpur lost territory and became subordinate allies with the British Raj as states that retain sovereignty under British paramountcy. Other small states also fell to the British Raj; at the end of the war every Maratha power surrendered to the British, bearing the Treaty of Gwalior on November 5, 1817. One by one the states fell until the Peshwa, the last of the states, surrendered on June 3, 1818. The war saw the British East India Company control very nearly the entire subcontinent below the Sutlej River, recover the Nassak Diamond, claim much of the former Maratha Empire and in effect destroyed their most dynamic opposition.

The Cholas set up an embassy in China, which as well as conducting diplomacy, sold products to the Chinese. The embassy was apparently highly profitable for the Cholas.

For over 1000 years, the Chola dynasty lay at the southern tip of the Indian subcontinent. The empire was founded on fertile ground around the Kaveri river, and continued to grow for most of their history. While the exact origins of the Chola have never been discovered, they are believed to be descended from the Tamil dynasty, a similar culture in Southern India. The Chola grew as a trading empire, and reached the height of their power during the middle ages, through kings such as Rajaraja Chola I and Rajendra Chola I, both capable military and expansive leaders. However, the empire soon fell into decline, and with constant harassment by the Pandyas, the Chola dynasty were gone by the end of the 13th century.

The Chola heartlands are one of the hottest parts of India, with temperatures above 27 degrees Celsius on average. To the west of this lies a far cooler, more moderate climate of around 20 degrees, which they also ruled over. Again, while the eastern part of the territory has a tropical savannah climate, the east has a wet tropical, creating a large geographical difference between the sides of the empire.

Ancient cultures in the south of India date back to 8000 BC. Items found around the area include stone axes and basic copper tools. The region is believed to have entered the Iron Age around 1000 BC, although they never passed through a fully formed copper age. As time passed, the Pandyan Empire took the land in the South of India, an area known as "Tamil". Although there were many competitors to the north to take the land, the Pandyas prevailed, and held the territory for quite a while. They were known for their mastery of the arts, but passed little on to successive dynasties. Throughout their ownership of the Tamil area, they had to fight against countless invaders, including the Kalabras, who put their history into dispute. However, this let an even more powerful empire take over in the region - they would quickly become known as the Cholas.

Over the course of around two-hundred years, the Chola dynasty became a prominent political entity in the region. The Cholas won over other dynasties in the region, including the Pandyas, and set out to forge an empire for themselves. However, they quickly fell into decline, presumable due to the invasion of the Kalabras. The Cholas stayed a strong state during the three-hundred years the Kalabras ruled over them, as they only really had control over the northern states, while the Chola heartlands were in the south. They maintained their influence in the region until the Kalabras had gone, and soon enough, the Chola empire was ready to re-establish itself.

Initially, the Cholas made little success in establishing a new empire. They had grown to take a lot of South India, although their power was constrained to that area. However, during the ninth century, the empire re-established itself under the rule of Raja Raja I. This say a series of political reforms, and the creation of a large sphere of influence that spanned most of East India and Western Indochina. The empire continued to grow through the reign of Rajendra Chola, with the establishment of more trade links to places like China and Surabaya. This was the largest the empire had grown to - its power was not just concentrated in the Chola state, but throughout many areas of the empire.

The empire's glory days had come and gone, and while it was still a prominent political entity after the tenth century, they had lost most of their power in the regions to the east of the central government. Instead, the empire focused on expanding their domains to the north of the main Chola area, undertaking several wars to take that territory. During this period, they also had a focus on the arts, and made several statues to honour the leaders of the past, in the glory days now long-gone. They still maintained their trade routes to China, and had ones to the Malays as well, but their influence had demised to the point that the empire wasn't a shadow of its former self. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE] However, a lot of the emperors of the declining dynasty were still very able leaders, so the empire, while not nearly as prosperous as it once was, still enjoyed a high standard of living, with policies focused far more on maritime trade than war.

In 1070, a succession crisis was triggered when the king died, and his son was assassinated shortly after him. There were several people in line for the throne at this point, and over about fifty years, a lot of the north of the empire was lost before the crisis could be solved. Kulothunga Chola I, who ruled through these troubled times, was actually a very able monarch, but was undermined by the amount of problems he faced, rendering most of the empire lost. By the time his son came to the throne, it was only about a third as large as the empire that his father had inherited. By 1246, the empire was diminished to a small entity around the Kaveri River, and at the end of the 13th centary, the Cholas had passed into history, under the authority of the Pandyas once more.

While the dynasty may be gone, the Cholas have left a legacy in the buildings and monuments they constructed around Southern India. They are known today as master architects, with buildings such as the Brihadeeswarar Temple, which is part of a site called "Great Living Chola Temples", due to the large number of Chola temples in the area. They are known in paticular for the scale and detail gone into these constructions. As well as the temples they built, they also has a vast body of writing. A lot of books are about Hinduism (the primary religion of the Cholas), with a lot also being dedicated to poetry, and a vast number about the empire itself. While a lot of the empires in the north of India were Islamic, the Chola Dynasty were Hindu, and to this day, India remains a mostly Hindu state, perhaps thanks to the once-mighty kingdom in the south. All in all, the Chola dynasty was one that truly shaped India, and with its buildings and books to show its lasting legacy, the Cholas are undeniably one of the most important groups in India's long history.

The Maurya Empire was an Iron Age power in ancient India. Established by Chandragupta Maurya in 322 BC, the Maurya Empire expanded westward, quickly claiming control of central and western India and exploiting the local disruptions due to Alexander the Great withdrawal. The Maurya Empire was the largest empire on the subcontinent and one of the largest in the world.

Much of the Maurya Empire encompassed all of what is now India - the subcontinent is a large tropical plain bordered by the Himalaya Mountains, the Indian Ocean and the Arabian Sea. The peninsula itself is very flat and is littered with rivers cutting every which way across the plain, the largest of these being the Indus River.
Fallout from the Death of Alexander

The Maurya Empire was founded during what would turn out to be a tumultuous time; as Chandragupta Maurya and Chanakya, a Brahmin teacher from Takshashila traveled to Magadha - a large, powerful kingdom feared by its neighbors, the ever-growing power of Alexander the Great and his Macedonians refused to cross the River Beas to further push into India, deterred by the same fear of the Magadha. Alexander returned to Babylon and re-deployed the bulk of his forces west of the Indus river. When Alexander died in 323 BC his empire fractured, the local kings claimed independence and thus fought each other. This left several smaller satrapies in disunity, territories ripe for conquest.

Chanakya, made an advisor by Chandragupta, encouraged him and the army to claim the throne of Magadha. Chandragupta used his influence to discover many young men from the Magadha kingdom upset over the oppressive rule of the king Dhana and the resources for his long series of battles. In these ranks were the former general of Taxila, the representative of King Porus of Kakayee, and rulers of smaller states.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Preparing for the invasion of Pataliputra, Chandragupta developed a strategy. The Magadhan army drew out of the city to engage the Mauryan forces, meanwhile the Mauryan spies bribed the general of Nanda and caused civil unrest in the kingdom - the unrest led to the death of the heir to the throne. Chanakya was able to win popularity for Chandragupta. Nanda resigned, handing control of the city to the Mauryans. Chanakya then met with the prime minister of Magadha, Rakshasa and made him understand that his loyalty was not to the Nanda dynasty but Magadha, insisting he remain in office. Chanakya then threatened war that would cripple the kingdom. Rakshasa accepted and Chandragupta was made the King of Magadha, Rakshasa became his chief advisor and Chanakya an elder statesman.

Chandragupta turned his attention to the Macedonians when Seleucus I Nicator, when trying to build the Seleucid Empire, tried to recapture the northwestern regions of India in 305 BC. Seleucus failed and the two rulers came to an agreement where the Greeks offered their princess and the satrapies of Paropamisade, Arachosia and Gedrosia, and the Mauryans offered 500 war elephants that ultimately played a role in Seleucus' victory in the Battle of Ipsus. Diplomacy was established with the Greeks and several Greeks such as Megasthenes, Deimakos and Dionysius lived at the Mauryan court. From this Chandragupta established a strong centralized state with a complex administration at Pataliputra. The historian Megasthenes described the city as being "surrounded by a wooden wall pierced by 64 gates and 570 towers - and rivaled the splendors of contemporaneous Persian sites such as Susa and Ecbatana."

Bindusara was the son of Chandragupta Maurya and his queen Durdhara; during his reign he would push the frontiers of the empire south. According to the Rajavalikatha - a Jain text - the original name of the emperor was Simhasena. The legend tells the tale of his birth; Chanakya used to feed Chandragupta small doses of poison in an effort to create an immunity against it should enemies attempt to poison him. One day, unaware of Chanakya's practices, Chandragupta shared his food with his pregnant wife who was a week away from delivery. Without this immunity the queen collapsed and died in just a few minutes. Chanakya entered just as she fell and, in order to save the unborn child, he immediately cut open her belly and took out the baby. A drop of poison already reached the baby and touched its head, discoloring his forehead with a permanent bluish spot - a "bindu". The young heir was thus named Bindusara.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]At just 22 Bindusara inherited the Mauryan Empire - what is now regions of Northern, Central and Eastern India and parts of Afghanistan and Baluchistan. Bindusara expanded to the southern regions of India, as far as what is now Karnataka. He brought sixteen states under Mauryan control and conquered almost the entire Indian peninsula, he is said to have claimed the 'land between the two seas' - this is the peninsula area between the Bay of Bengal and the Arabian Sea. Apart from the friendly Dravidian kingdoms of the Cholas, the Pandyas and Cheras, the only southern kingdom that did not fall to Bindusara was Kalinga in modern Odisha.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Bindusara's life is not well documented; Chanaka continued to serve as prime minister during his reign. According to the Tibetan scholar Taranatha when he visited India, Chanakya helped Bindusara "to destroy the noble kings of the sixteen kingdoms and thus become absolute master of the territory between the eastern and western oceans." The citizens of Taxila revolted twice during his rule; first was the maladministration of Suseema, Bindusara's eldest son. The reason for the second revolt is not known, but Bindusara could not suppress it in his lifetime. He died in 272 BC and was succeeded by his son Ashokavardhan Maurya, more commonly known as Ashoka the Great.

As a young prince Ashoka was an impressive commander, crushing the revolts in Ujjain and Taxila. As a monarch he was bold and aggressive, re-asserting the empire's superiority in the south and west; for more on his conquests and his life in general see his Civilopedia entry. However it was between 262 and 261 BC where a pivotal event changed Ashoka's life - the conquest of Kalinga. Ashoka's forces won overwhelmingly, yet the fact that approximately 100,000 soldiers and citizens were killed in the battle, including 10,000 of Ashoka's men, wrangled Ashoka. Hundreds of thousands of people had become affected by the fallout of the battle, witnessing this himself Ashoka felt remorseful - so much so that even with the annexation of Kalinga Ashoka accepted and embraced Buddhism, renouncing violence and war. He sent out missionaries to travel all over Asia to spread Buddhism to other civilizations.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Ashoka established principles of 'ahimsa' - meaning 'to do no harm' - by banning hunting and violent sport, and ending indentured and forced labor - thousands of people in Kalinga had been forced into hard labor and servitude. Even though he did maintain an army, mainly to keep the peace and authority, Ashoka extended friendly relations with countries across Europe and Asia, sponsoring Buddhist missions. Ashoka undertook a large public works campaign across the empire. With over four decades of peace, harmony and prosperity during his reign Ashoka is one of the most successful and famous kings in Indian history and remains an idealized figure of inspiration in the country today.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The Edicts of Ashoka are set in stones throughout the Subcontinent; as far west as Afghanistan and as far south as Andhra. The edicts state his laws and accomplishments during his reign. The edicts also attest to Ashoka having sent envoys to the Greek rulers in the West as far as the Mediterranean, going so far as to name each of the rulers of the Hellenic world at the time such as 'Amtiyoko', 'Tulamaya' and 'Alikasudaro' - Antiochus, Ptolemy and Alexander respectively.

After Ashoka's death in 232 BC followed 50 years of weaker kings. Brihadratha was the last Mauryan ruler of the dynasty and held a nation much smaller from Ashoka's reign, though he still upheld the Buddhist faith. Brihadratha was assassinated in 185 BC during a military parade by the Brahmin general Pusyamitra Sunga, the commander of his guard, who then took the throne and established the Sunga dynasty. Buddhist records write that the assassination and the rise of the Sunga empire led to a wave of persecution against Buddhists and a resurgence of Hinduism. Scholars tend to differ as to the legitimacy of these records.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The fall of the Mauryans left the Khyber Pass unguarded and a wave of foreign invasion followed soon after. The Greco-Bactrian king Demetrius capitalized on the break up and took southern Afghanistan and parts of northern India by about c. 180 BC, creating the Indo-Greek Kingdom. The Indo-Greeks maintained the land in the trans-Indus region and raided parts of central India for about a century until roughly c. 70 BC when the Indo-Scythians invaded and succeeded.

Ashoka's edicts refer to the Greeks, Kambojas and Gandharas as peoples forming a frontier region of his empire.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Historians believe that the organization of the empire was in line with the extensive bureaucracy mentioned by Kautilya int he Arthashastra; a sophisticated civil service governed everything from hygiene to international trade.
