Akbar was the third Mughal Emperor, ascending in 1556. In that time Akbar would become the greatest ruler of the empire; expanding the Mughal sphere of influence, adopting a policy to conciliate defeated rulers through marriage and diplomacy, winning support from non-Muslim citizens through tolerance policies and strove to unite lands through loyalty expressed through the Persianised culture. As a patron of culture Akbar established the foundations of a multicultural Mughal empire and won the trust of the native Indians for the first time in the history of the empire.

Born on October 14, 1542 in Umerkot as Badruddin, Akbar's parents Humayun and Hamida Banu Begum sought refuge in the town from the loss of Kabul. Humayun reclaimed Kabul some weeks later and performed Akbar's circumcision ceremony there, they also changed his name to Jalal-ud-din Muhammad - a name Humayun heard in a dream in Lahore. The conflict with the Pashtun leader Sher Shah Suri drove Humayun and Hamida Banu to Persia in exile, Akbar however grew up in the village of Mukundpur in present-day Madhya Pradesh. Akbar grew up with prince Ram Singh I wher they became good friends; Akbar later moved to the eastern Safavid Empire where he was risen by his uncle Mirza Askari, there he learnt to hunt, run and fight - he to become a skilled warrior who then never learnt to read. Ironically even at youth he pursued knowledge as it is said he rested in the evening having someone read to him. In November 1551 Akbar married his first cousin, Ruqaiya Sultan Begum in Jaladhar.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Following the turmoil over the succession of Suri's son Islam Shah, Humayun reconquered Delhi in 1555 with an army partly provided by his Persian ally Tahmasp I. Months later Humayun fell from the top of the Din Panah building; concealing the manner of his death Akbar's guardian, Bairam Khan prepared Akbar for his succession. His succession was during the conflict with the Sur leader Sikandar Shah, to reclaim the Mughal throne. By the age of 13, in Kalanaur in Punjab, Akbar was enthroned by Bairamand proclaimed 'Shahanshah' - meaning 'King of kings' - where Bairam Khan ruled on Akbar's behalf until he came of age.

Before Akbar's ascension Humayun claimed control of the Punjab, Delhi and Agra with support from Persia; due to the Surs victories in claiming the throne the control of these areas were precarious, adding to that no support would be earned from the Persians as Kabul was in the throws of its own invasion by the leader of Badakhshan, Prince Mirza Suleiman. The young emperor's future was unclear. His regent Bairam Khan called a war council to marshal the forces but none of the chieftains approved the idea, Bairam prevailed over them and the Mughals would engage the Surs in the Punjab. Sikandar Shah was of no genuine threat to Akbar, avoiding battle as the Mughals approached. Hemu was the greatest threat, as a minister and general to one of the Sur rulers he proclaimed himself Hindu emperor and expelled the Mughals from the Indo-Gangetic plains.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Spurred on by Bairam Khan who himself marshalled the Mughal army before Hemu consolidated his position, Akbar marched to Delhi and by the start of 1557 the Mughals captured the city and Agra. Akbar entered Delhi in a triumph where he stayed for a month, until he and Bairam returned to Punjab to deal with the now active Sikandar Shah. For six months the Mughals gained another major victory against the Sur who fled east to Bengal, as he did Akbar occupied Lahore and seized Multan. By the end of 1558 the Mughals claimed Ajmer from the Muslim ruler there and a Mughal commander defeated the last Sur prince Ibrahim, claiming Jaunpur in the eastern Gengetic Valley. The Mughals also defeated the Sur controlling Gwalior Fort, the greatest stronghold north of the Narmada River. The flurry of victories brought the cities between Lahore, Delhi, Agra and Jaunpur under Mughal control, this presented the empire with the ability to tap the immense agricultural productivity and potential of trade. Royal begums came from Kabul as Akbar made his intentions clear - the Mughals are to remain in India.

By 1559 the Mughals began a drive south into Rajputana and Malwa, disputes between him and Bairam Khan however ended this temporarily. Urged by his relatives Akbar, now 18, wanted a more active role in management of the empire, after another dispute with the regent Akbar dismissed Bairam Khan in the spring of 1560, ordering him to leave and travel to Mecca. Bairam did, but was goaded by oppoition to rebel, he was defeated by the Mughal forces and forced to submit where Akbar forgave him and offered the choise to return to the court or continue to Mecca. Bairam chose the latter where during his journey he was assassinated by a vengeful Afghan. Akbar continued the push south, he sent his foster brother, Adham Khan with commander Pir Muhammad Khan and the army to invade Malwa. The Afghan ruler Baz Bahadur was defeated and fled to Khandesh for refuge leaving his harem, treasure and war elephants. In spite of the success Akbar suffered a disaster in that Adham retained all the spoils of war and killed the surrendered garrison, their wives and children, and most Muslim theologians and Sayyids. Akbar rode the Malwa to confront his foster brother and relieve him of command, while Pir Muhammad marched to pursue Baz; he was beaten back by the alliance of the rulers of Khandesh and Berar. Baz Bahadur reclaimed Malwa until the next year Akbar again invaded and annexed Malwa, Baz survived as a refugee in various courts until in 1570 he took service under Akbar.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The Mughals conquered the Gondwana kingdom in 1564, predominantly for its herd of wild elephants. Akbar allowed the Mughal governor of Kara, Asaf Khan the task of capturing Gondwana as he himself was dealing with an Uzbek rebellion. Raja Vir Narayan, ruler of Gondwana fell in the Fall of Chauragarh while his mother Durgavati committed suicide in the Battle of Damoh. The conquest added gold, silver and jewels in the Mughal coffers, 1000 elephants to the herd, the younger sister of Durgavati into the harem and installed the brother of Durgavati's husband as the Mughal administer in the region. Once again however this also caused a dispute with Akbar's vassals, Asaf Khan sent Akbar only 200 of the elephants and when summoned to give accoutns he fled. Asaf went to the Uzbeks to rally an army to pursued the Mughals forces for the kingdom; defeated, Asaf Khan submitted and Akbar restored his previous position.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Establishing Mughal control in northern India Akbar pursued further south to Rajputana, concluding that no imperial power in India based in the plains could be safe if a rival power dwelt in the region. Mughal influence already exsisted in Mewat, Ajmer and Nagor, Akbar was determined to drill straight into the homelands of the Rajput kings; further than any of the Muslim rulers of the Delhi Sultanate. Starting in 1561 the Mughals engaged the Rajputs in battle and diplomacy; most of the Rajput states ceded to Akbar, the ruler of Mewar Udai Singh, however remained defiant. As the head of the Sisodia clan Raja Udai Singh claimed the highest ritual status of the Rajput kings in India, unless he submitted the authority of the Mughals would be lessened in the eyes of the Rajputs. Further working against Akbar was still his devotion to Islam, seeking to impress the superiority of his faith over the Brahminical Hinduism of the warriors.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]In 1567 Akbar marched to claim and reduce the Chittorgarh Fort in Mewar, the fort was a strategic location to take as it lay on the shortest route between Agra and Gujarat and was a key to hold the interior of Rajputana. Udai left two generals, Jaimal and Patta to defend the fort as he retired to the hills, Chittorgarh fell on Febuary 1568. As a show of authority Akbar killed the surviving defenders and displayed their heads on towers throughout the region. After three days in the fort Akbar returned to Agra where to celebrate the victory he commissioned statues depicting Jaimal and Patta on elephants at the gates of his fort. Udai Singh's power was broken and he never left the moutain refuge in Mewar, this suited Akbar and he left him as the Mughals continued to invade Ranthambore Fort the same year. In 1569 Akbar founded the city of Fatehpur Sikri, meaning 'the City of Victory', to commemorate his conquest of Rajputana, a feat only completed in 1576 when Pratap Singh, Udai's son, was defeated in the Battle of Haldighati.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Akbar would continue his campaigning to conquer Western and Eastern India, parts of Afghanistan, the Indus Valley, Baluchistan and Kandahar.

Akbar had a great interest in religious and philosophical matters, as an orthodox Muslim originally he later came to be influenced by Sufi preached in the empire at the time. This influence moved him to appoint in his court several talented people with liberal ideas, including Abul Fazl, Faizi and Birbal. In 1575 in Fatehpur Sikri Akbar built a hall known as the Ibadat Khana - meaning House of Worship - in order to invite theologians, mystics and courtiers known for their intellect to discuss matters of spirituality with them all. Originally restricted to Muslims, these forums were acrimonious and often resulted in the participants shouting and hurling abuse at each other. Upset by this Akbar opened the Ibadat Khana to people of any religion, including atheists, resulting in a broader discussion - even into areas such as the validity of the Quran and the nature of God. Naturally this shocked the orthodox theologians and motivated them to discredit Akbar by spreading rumours of his want to forsake Islam. This even caused a number of his brilliant courtiers to criticize Akbar's chioces, decisions and regulations - amongst other things - regarding religious matters.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Akbar's attempts to reach a common meeting point among the intellects was not going well, each tried to assert the superiority of their religion and denounce the others. This resulted in the debating in the Ibadat Khana to grow more acrimonious and unintentionally fostered a bitterness among each other; by 1582 Akbar discontinued the discussions, but the interaction did convince him that beyond the differences of each religion they all had several good practices. This drove him to combine these into a new religion movement known as Dīn-i Ilāhī, meaning 'Religion of God'. Dīn-i Ilāhī was more a system of ethics that is said to have prohibited lust, sensuality, slander and pride - each considered as sins, and piety, prudence, abstinence and kindness core virtues; the soul is encouraged to purify itself through the yearning of God. Celibacy was respected, chastity was enforced, the slaughter of animals was forbidden and there were no sacred scriptures or priestly hierarchy. Akbar changed the name of the city of Prayag to Allahabad to commemorate Dīn-i Ilāhī. Sulh-e-kul, the system that formed the essence of Dīn-i Ilāhī, was adopted by Akbar not just as a religious system but also as a general administrative policy; this formed the basis of his religious toleration. By the death of Akbar in 1605 the policy showed no discontent amongst either the Muslims nor that of the Hindus.

On October 3, 1605 Akbar was struck with dysentery which he never recovered from, dying on the 27th of that month. He was buried in a mausoleum in Sikandra in Agra. In 1691, three quarters of a century later, a group of Hindu rebels known as the Jats broke into the mausoleum, stealing the gold, silver and carpets in it, and dragged his remains from the structure and burnt him.

Akbar gained the title 'Akbar the Great' from his impressive military campaigns and unbeaten record. As a military leader he dominated the field of battle at every conflict, ballooning the once fledgling state kingdom to a massive subcontinental empire, unifying much of the Indian kingdoms to his rule. Akbar encouraged trade between the kingdoms and tolerance between the religions, unifying the Muslim imperialists with the Hindu natives as a single people. Akbar implanted the notion of pluralism and tolerance into the Indian people that now underlies the values of the modern republic of India. Citing this, Time magazine includes Akbar in its top 25 world leaders.

Shivaji Bhosale was the founder of the Maratha Empire, he led a resistance against the Adilshahi Sultanate of Bijapur and the Mughal Empire to establish a Hindavi Swarajya, meaning a 'self-rule of Hindu people'. He created the independent kingdom, placing Raigad as the capital and was crowned Chhatrapati, meaning 'paramount sovereign', in 1674. During his rule Shivaji established a progressive rule with the help of a well trained army and organized administrations. He innovated battlefield tactics, developed guerrilla warfare methods and focused pinpoint attacks to defeat his larger and more powerful enemies. From just 2000 men Shivaji inflated the army to 100,000, he built and repaired many forts to defend his land and revived ancient Hindu political traditions and court conventions, promoting the use of Marathi and Sanskrit to Persian in the administration.

Sometime around 1627 Shivaji was born in the hill fort of Shivneri, near Jaipur. Other dates suggest specifically April 6 of that year, while another suggests February 19, 1630. Legend holds that his mother named him Shivaji to honor the goddess Shivai who she prayed the baby be born healthy. His father, Shahaji Bhosale was the leader of a band of mercenaries serving in the Deccan Sultanates; his mother, Jijabai was the daughter of Lakhuji Rao Jadhav of Sindkhed. At the time of Shivaji's birth the Deccan was shared between three Islamic sultanates; Bijapur, Ahmednagar and Golconda. As a mercenary for hire Shahaji often changed loyalties between the Nizamshahi of Ahmadnagar, the Adilshah of Bijapur and the Mughals, but he kept his jagir - or fiefdom - in Pune and his army with him. Following a treaty between the Mughals and the Bijaput Sultanate Shahji was posted in a Bangalore-based jagir while Jijabai and Shivaji stayed in Pune.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Shivaji was very devoted to his mother, Jijabai was very religious and the religious environment drove him to study the Hindu epics - Ramayana and Manabharata, these influenced his lifelong defense of Hindu values. Shivaji took great interest in religious teachings and regularly found the company of Hindu and Sufi saints. In that time Shahaji married another wife, Tuka Bai Mohite; he moved on to assign himself in Karnataka and entrusted his younger son and Jijabai with his friend Dadoji Kondadev Kulkarni, providing a mansion administered by the jagir. Kulkarni mentored the young Shivaji, proving himself a keen outdoorsman but lacking a formal education and was most likely illiterate. Shivaji drew his earliest trusted generals and a number of soldiers from the Maval region to remain with him in Pune, in their company he set off over the hills and into the forests of the Sahyadri range; there he hardened himself and gained knowledge of the land about him and the region. At the age of 12 Shivaji was sent to Bangalore where he and his elder brother Smabhaji and stepbrother Ekoji I all received further training. Shivaji married Saibai, a member of the rising Nimbalkar family, in 1640. At age 14 Shivaji returned to Pune with a rajmudra, meaning 'sovereign seal', and a ministerial court; around 1645 he first expressed the notion of Hindavi Swarajya in a letter to Dadaji Naras Prabhu.

That year, at the age of 16 Shivaji bribed the Bijapuri commander, Inayat Khan to hand control of Torna Fort to Shivaji; Firangoji Narsala professed loyalty to Shivaji and handed the Chakan fort to him and the Adilshahi governor gave him the fort of Kondana for a bribe. On July 25, 1649 Adilshah Mohammed Adil Shah attempted to contain Shivaji's domain by sending Baji Ghorpade to imprison his father; accounts vary as to Shahaji's captivity with his release ranging from 1649 to 1655. Whichever the case, upon his release Shahaji retired from his duties and lived privately until 1665 in a hunting accident. After the morning of his father Shivaji continued the raiding and claimed the kingdom of Javali from another Maratha chieftain.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]During 1659 the Adilshah sent Afzal Khan, a veteran and experienced general to eliminate Shivaji and quash what he saw as a regional revolt. Khan desecrated Hindu temples at Tuljapur and Pandharpur in an effort to draw Shivaji to the plains, a battlefield the Bijapuri army could destroy him; in response Shivaji sent Khan a letter to negotiate. On November 10 that year they met in a hut at the foothills of Pratapgad. The arrangement dictated they armed with just a sword and attended by a follower, suspecting an attack from Khan or planning to himself Shivaji work armor under his clothes, had a dagger in his right hand and concealed a bagh nakh, meaning 'tiger claw' - it is a metal claw weapon to fit over the knuckles, on his left arm. Accounts vary as to who started the fight, but both the Maratha and Persian chronicles notate Khan's dagger hitting Shivaji's armor and Shivaji mortally injuring Khan, Shivaji then signaled his hidden troop to assault the Bijapuri army.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The assault is known as the Battle of Pratapgarh, Shivaji defeated the forces with the infantry's speed and cavalry's agility hammering the Bijapuri army. The unlikely victory made Shivaji a hero of the Maratha and a legend. The captured weapons, horses, armor and other materials strengthen the emerging Maratha army to the point that the Mughal emperor Aurangzeb saw Shivaji as a major threat to the empire. Soon after Shivaji, Shahaji and the chief of the cavalry, Netaji Palkar decided to attack and defeat the Adilshahi kingdom at Bijapur. Shahaji's health took a turn for the worse though and the attack was postponed, in the meantime Palkar continued to harass the Adilshahi with further attacks. To reverse the loss at Pratapgarh and defeat the Maratha a larger army was sent to met and destroy Shivaji under the leadership of general Rustamjaman. On December 28, 1659 Shivaji met him with 5000 cavalry near Kolhapur, outnumbered two to one Shivaji soundly defeated the Bijapuri again after several hours of battle, Rustamjaman fled the battlefield and the Battle of Kolhapur alarmed Aurangazeb to address the rising threat, calling Shivaji the "Mountain Rat".[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The following year the Adilshah sent his general Siddi Jauhar to attack the Marathai southern frontier in an allied battle with the Mughals who were to attack from the north. Shivaji was camped at Panhala Fort near the latest claim of Kolhapur. In mid 1660 Jauhar besieged the fort, Shivaji escaped and withdrew his forces to Rangna. Ali Adil Shah arrived at the field in person and after four months the fort fell to the Adilshah. During the siege Jauhar purchased grenades and hired artillerymen from the British in Rajapur, they conspicuously flew the Union Jack into battle. Deeply betrayed Shivaji sought vengeance and plundered the English factory at Rajapur, capturing four of the factors and imprisoning them until mid 1663.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Believing the enemies were quickly converging on him Shivaji now sought to avoid defeat. Baji Prabhu Deshpande, a Maratha sardar of Bandal Deshmukh, and 300 soldiers volunteered to fight the enemy at Ghod Khind and defend Shivaji to the death as he retreated to the Vishalgad Fort. This became the Battle of Pavan Khind on July 13, 1660, where the small Maratha force held back the enemy for many hours as Shivaji made his escape. Deshpande was injured in the ensuing battle but carried on fighting until he heard the sound of cannon fire from Vishalgad, the signal of Shivaji's arrival. A truce was made between Shivaji and the Adilshah through Shahaji; Panhala Fort was given to Jauhar and the site of Ghod Khind was renamed Paavan Khind, meaning 'sacred pass', to honor Deshpande and the soldiers who fought there.

Before 1657 Shivaji maintained peace with the Mughal Empire, Shivaji even offered aid to Aurangzeb in conquering Bijapur in exchange for the right to claim the forts and villages as his own. The wars began in March of that year when two of Shivaji's officers raided the Mughal owned Ahmednagar, and then followed by raids in Junnar where Shivaji claimed 300,000 hun in cash and 200 horses. Aurangzeb responded by sending Nasiri Khan to defeat the forces in Ahmednagar, this was held back during the rainy season and after the succession battle for the throne following the illness of Shah Jahan.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]By the request of Badi Begum of Bijapur the Mughal emperor sent his maternal uncle, Shaista Khan with an army of more than 150,000 and artillery to attack Shivaji in January 1660; this was the Mughal force that worked with the Adilshah general Siddi Jauhar. Better equipped and provisioned Khan seized Pune and the neighboring Chakan Fort, besieging it for one and a half months until breaching the walls. Khan pressed his advantage further by establishing his resistance at Shivaji's palace of Lal Mahal. In April 1663 Shivaji launched a surprise attack on Shaista Khan in Pune; the accounts vary once again but they agree that he and 200 followers infiltrated the city using a wedding procession as cover, they overcame the palace guards, breached the wall and entered Khan's quarters, killing all they crossed paths with. Shaista Khan himself escaped minus a thumb he lost in battle, but one of his sons and other members of the household fell in the assault. Khan took refuge outside Pune and Aurangzeb punished him for the embarrassment by tranfering him to Bengal. Shaista Khan later sent an Uzbek general, Kartalab Khan to attack Shivaji's forces in the Konkan region on February 3, 1661. In an attempt to surprise the Marathas the Mughal troops were in fact themselves surprise attacked by Shivaji in the Battle of Umberkhind. Foreseeing defeat the commander Raibagan advised Khan to parley with Shivaji; he allowed the Mughals to surrender their supplies and arms in exchange for safe passage home. Shivaji retaliated against Shaista Khan's attacks with the sacking of Surat in 1664, the attack also replenished the depleted Maratha coffers.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Infuriated by the attack Aurangzeb sent Mirza Raja Jai Singh I with an army 150,000 strong to annihilate Shivaji. Jai Singh was effective in battle, claiming a number of forts and thus forced Shivaji to come to terms with the emperor rather than run heavier loses. Shivaji and Jai Singh signed the Treaty of Purandar on June 11, 1665, Shivaji agreed to pass 23 forts to Mughal control and pay 400,000 rupees in compensation. The greater loss in the treaty was Shivaji's son Sambhaji to become a Mughal sardar and Shivaji himself would serve in the Mughal court and fight with the Mughals against Bijapur. Shivaji's commander Netaji Palkar joined the Mughals; Palkar was rewarded handsomely, converted to Islam and changed his name to Quli Mohammed Khan the following year where he was sent to fight tribes in the Afghan borders. Palkar returned to both Marathi and Shivaji's service in 1676 and was accepted back as a Hindu.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]On May 12, 1666 Aurangzeb invited Shivaji and his son to Agra; the emperor's plan was simply to send Shivaji to Kandahar to consolidate the northwest frontier of the empire, but during the meeting in the court the emperor made Shivaji stand behind military commanders - Shivaji took great offense to this and stormed out of the court. Aurangzeb placed him under house arrest and placed the Kotwal of Agra, Faulad Khan to keep a watch on him. During the arrest spies informed Shivaji of Aurangzeb's plans to move him to Raja Vitthaldas' residence and possibly kill him there or send Shivaji to fight in the Afghan frontiers, Shivaji schemed escape. Feigning illness Shivaji requested most of his men back to the Deccan, ensuring their safety, and sent daily offerings of sweets to saints, fakirs and temples in Agra to bless him for better health. Being a nine year old child Sambhaji could freely leave the prison camp, Shivaji disguised himself as a laborer carrying sweets on August 17, 1666. They both fled to the Deccan disguised as sadhus, 'holy men', and after the escape Shivaji spread the rumor of his son's death in order to protect him.

With Shivaji's escape hostilities ebbed and the established treaty ended by the end of 1670 when he launched a major offensive, in four months most of the territory lost five years before were recovered in this single campaign. In it the Marathas won the fort of Sinhgad with the general, Tanaji Malusare falling in the process, and the second sacking of Surat; the Mughals tried to intercept Shivaji after the sacking but lost in the Battle of Vani-Dindori.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]In October 1670 Shivaji once again harassed the British in Bombay as they refused to sell him war material, he blocked the woodcutting parties. The following year Shivaji sent an ambassador to Bombay to again request material to fight Danda-Rajpuri, but the British had misgivings with the implications of Shivaji's advantages in the conquest, but the British also didn't want to miss the opportunity to gain compensation for his looting in Rajapur many years before. The British East India Company sent Lieutenant Stephen Ustick to treat with Shivaji, but negotiations failed over indemnity. In the following years envoys would continue to met and discuss the matter; agreement was reached to the issue of arms in 1674 but Shivaji would never pay the Rajapur indemnity before his death, and from that the affected factory dissolved in 1682.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]In 1674 the commander of the Maratha forces, Prataprao Gujar was sent to repel an invasion force led by Adilshahi general Bahlol Khan. Gujar was successful in this and captured Khan in battle, but Khan sued for peace. Shivaji warned Gujar against peace with the general, but Gujar released him and upon reaching safely Khan prepared for the next invasion. Upset by the turn of events Shivaji sent a letter to Gujar, refusing him audience until a re-capture was made. Shivaji and Gujar learned of a force of 15,000 camped at Nesari led by Bahlol Khan. However, not wanting to risk losing the smaller Maratha force entirely, Gujar and six of his sardars attacked the force in a suicide mission, buying time for Anandrao Mohite to withdraw the army to safety. The Marathas avenged the death of Prataprao Gujar by defeated Khan and capturing his jagir under the leadership of Anaji and Hambirao Mohite, the new commander of the Maratha forces. Raigad Fort was newly built as a capital of the Maratha kingdom.

Shivaji gained many territories and great wealth through the campaigns, but lacked a formal title; due to this Shivaji was still technically a Mughal zamindar or the son of an Adilshahi jagirdar, and could not rule a de facto domain. A title would address this and in turn prevent challenges from the rest of the Maratha leaders, who at this time were still Shivaji's equals, and provide the Hindu Marathas with a Hindu sovereign in a region otherwise ruled by Muslims. Thus Shivaji was crowned king of the Marathas at Raigad on June 6, 1674. Pandit Gaga Bhutt officiated, holding a vessel filled with the seven sacred waters over Shivaji's head and chanted the mantras. Shivaji bowed before his mother Jijabai in a ceremony seen by approximately 50,000 people, he was entitled Shakakarta, Kshatriya Kulavantas and Chhatrapati - meaning "founder of an era", "head of Kshatriyas" and "paramount sovereign" respectively. Twelve days after Jijabai died; seen as a bad omen a second coronation ceremony was held on September 24, 1674 and was precised over by Nischal Puri. At the time of the coronation the Maratha state was a kingdom, it would become a full-fledged empire a century later.

With the kingdom established Shivaji returned to his expansionist campaigns, raiding Khandesh, capturing Bijapuri Phonda, claiming Karwar and Kolhapur by mid 1675. The navy engaged with the Siddis of Janjira and Peshwa Pingale fought the Raja of Ramnagar en route to Surat in 1676. By the end of the year Shivaji raided Athani, besieged Belgaum and Vayem Rayim and captured the forts of Vellore and Gingee. Shivaji called for a sense of Deccani patriotism in southern India, proclaiming it a homeland that should be protected from outsiders. The proclamation led to a treaty with the Qutubshah of Golconda in the eastern Deccan.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]In late March 1680 Shivaji fell ill with fever and dysentery, dying in early April that year. Succession was a complex issue as his eldest son Sambhaji was irresponsible and "addicted to sensual pleasures". Shivaji confined him to Panhala in 1678 where Sambhaji and his wife escaped and defected to the Mughals for a year. Sambhaji returned afterward without regret for his actions and was again confined the Panhala. Shivaji's widow, Soyarabai planned with ministers to install her ten year old son Rajaram to the throne, having done so on April 21, 1680. Sambhaji captured Raigad Fort, killing the commander there and by June 18 took control of the city itself, ascending in July 20. This would eventually become the Maratha War of Independence as the Mughals seized the chance to claim Maratha in the ensuing instability.

As a warlord Shivaji made great feats on the battlefield, launching surprise attacks and constantly resisting the Persianized rulers, as a patriot he embodied the spirit of nationalism in the Hindu population in the Deccan as he finally asserted independence in the final years before his death. Nineteenth century revivalist Swami Vivekanada paid many tributes to the hero and best describes Shivaji's mark in history: "Shivaji is one of the greatest saviors who emancipated our society and our Hindu dharma when they were faced with the threat of total destruction. He was a peerless hero, a pious and God-fearing king and verily a manifestation of all the virtues of a born leader of men described in our ancient scriptures. He also embodied the deathless spirit of our land and stood as the light of hope for our people."
Despite being brought up in a somewhat restrictive Hindu sect, Raja Raja was fairly tolerant towards other faiths and beliefs.

Rajaraja Chola I is considered one of the greatest ever Indian kings and possibly the greatest leader of the Chola. Born Arulmozhi Varman, he was the third child of the king, and was never declared the crown prince. However, he proved himself on the battlefield, and soon enough, his rise to power was complete. Rajaraja soon attacked neighbouring states, by land and sea, and put the Chola Empire in the best possession it had ever been in. Towards the end of his reign, he left the state in a peaceful place, leaving a legacy to secure his place in history.

As a child, Raja Raja Chola (or Arulmozhi) was not brought up in the lavish lifestyle of a stereotypical prince. Although he did live a life of luxury, he was often on the battlefield, expanding the kingdom. According to a lot of sources, Raja Raja had no intention of becoming king, although his older siblings often bickered about it due to their right to rule. He was named a pince of the Chola Dynasty, and kept on fighting in several wars, until he was democratically elected as ruler of the empire, over his older siblings. According to some inscriptions, Raja Raja was a form of, or at least the image of Vishnu, a supreme deity in Hinduism, having allegedly had marks to show his place as the god. Some scholars believe that Raja Raja initially had no intention of inheriting the kingdom because he instead wanted to build up the military might and resources to get ready himself for war once he ascended to the throne.

Although many people believe that Raja Raja was at war from the early days of his reign, there is no evidence that he actually went to war until his eighth year in power. This is presumably because he wanted to finish the constriction of a massive army, capable of wiping out any enemy. Many kingdoms in the south, including the once - powerful Pandyas, were allied against the Chola dynasty, so Raja Raja sought to destroy them. He started his exceptional campaign by destroying a fleet in Kerala, which was altogether successful for the Cholas. He continued this campaign by going round the rest of the Pandyas lands, and soon enough assumed the title "Mummudi-Chola", or "the Chola king who wears three crowns", referencing his now-enlarged empire. Several poems were written about his expeditions, including one about the killing of eighteen princes as revenge for an insult dealt to him. Raja Raja grew his empire further up India's west coast, but stopped part way up. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE] Raja Raja's next target was Sri Lanka - a fairly large island just to the south of the Chola territory. In 1017, he captured the whole island, although it was reconquered before the end of the century.

After winning many naval battles, Raja Raja's attention turned to the north of India. Little by little, he attacked kingdoms to the north, and took the entire Ganga country. It is still unclear as to why Raja Raja put so much focus into these wars, as he already had a large amount of the territory to the north, but nevertheless, he did extremely well in his conquest of the area. The war in the north had almost been constant throughout his reign, and his next targets were the Chalukyas, another dynasty whom the Cholas had a rivalry with. Raja Raja enjoyed success in the early days of the war, but the enemy soon struck back at them. By the end of the war, the new boundary was established at the Tungabadhra River. Next, Raja Raja attacked the Vengi, proven by several temples and Chola Naval bases in the territory. The last land target for Raja Raja was Kalinga, which he took without much difficulty. The Chola's new aim was to gain supreme naval dominance in the region, which was made easy by Raja Raja's already proven skill on the water.

The Chola navy were an expert military force, who had assisted in the invasion of Sri Lanka, as well as the wars against the Pandyas. According to Rajaraja, there were around 12,000 islands out there that needed to fall under Chola dominance. The islands he spoke of were this time in the far east of the empire, around the present-day Indonesian islands. The navy used had improved since the times of Rajaraja's father, and was now ready to be utilised as an invasion force for any nation, seeing as the Chola navy was the first ever in India, and thus the only one on the continent, letting him take a lot of the Indochinese peninsula and the south-east Asian archipelago with relative ease. As well as expanding the empire far beyond the homeland, the Chola dynasty demanded tribute from several smaller states around the area. This empire was now one of the biggest in Asia, with possibly the most effective use of a naval force this far into history.

After the multitude of wars in his reign, Rajaraja settled down to a period of peace and prosperity for the empire. The trade was still doing fine in the area; the empire was now huge, at its largest until Rajendra would come along. A lot of resources were dedicated to the architecture going on in the region, and soon, the Cholas were one of the leading nations in the Indian subcontinent. A lot of records were made of the events that happened during Rajaraja's reign, hence why we have a very clear image of what his policies were and how his reign unfolded. Raja Raja died in 1014, with an empire several times larger than any of his predecessors had ruled over.

Today, Rajaraja I Chola is known as a warrior king who dramatically expanded the borders of his empire. He made the Chola a feared naval power in the region, and probably made the largest advancements towards the Cholas becoming a powerhouse in the area than any other person in the dynasty. As well as being a highly capable general, Raja Raja was incredibly good at administration the newly-conquered territories, which is why the new empire didn't fall apart almost instantly. He also built many great buildings in the Chola heartlands and beyond, and to the best of our knowledge, the buildings still exist today. Raja Raja I Chola was a fantastic ruler in times of both war and peace, and was able to make sure that as well as not getting defeated, the Chola Dynasty made several gains. He is mostly remembered today as the forefather of the Chola supremacy in the region, and continues to be known as a great tactician and politician.

Ashoka Maurya was an emperor of the Maurya dynasty and one of the greatest leaders in Indian history. He originally stretched the empire to cover nearly the entire subcontinent; from Khorasan and parts of ancient Afghanistan, through the Hindu Kush mountains to Bangladesh and Assam and as far south as Kerala and Andhra Pradesh. However Ashoka is mostly remembered for the battle against Kalinga where he ultimately adopted Buddhism and renounced violence. In his edicts Ashoka is referred to as Devanampriya - "the Beloved of the Gods" - and Priyadarsin - "He who regards everyone with affection".

Born in the capital of Pataliputra, Ashoka was the son of emperor Bindusara and Dharma, a lower ranked wife of his, although texts tend to differ over his mother; the Avadana suggest his mother to be Queen Subhadrang. It is from her exclamation "I am now without sorrow," where Ashoka got his name. The Divyavadana tells a similar story, the queen is named Janapadakalyani. Ashoka had several older siblings; all of them were half-brothers from Bindusara's other wives. As a child his fighting abilities were apparent, where he received royal military training. Ashoka was known as a fearsome hunter; legend suggests that he killed a lion with just a wooden stick. Due to this reputation of a fierce warrior and a heartless general Ashoka was sent to quash the riots in the Avanti province of the empire.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The Divyavadana continues to tell Ashoka's story, the text describes Ashoka putting down a revolt caused by the activities of corrupt ministers. Chanakya, one of Bindusara's great lords - and the same lord who advised Chandragupta Maurya - destroyed the nobles and kings of 16 towns and laid claim to all the land between the eastern and western seas. Historians differ as to the proceeding events that ensued as a result; most understand this as an indication of Bindusara's conquest of the Deccan. Nonetheless following the suppression of the revolt Ashoka was stationed at Ujjayini as governor. Bindusara's death by 273 BC led to a war over succession. The Divyavadana tells that Bindusara wanted his son Sushim to succeed, but Ashoka was supported by the late emperor's ministers, suggesting Sushim as arrogant and disrespectful. One of the ministers, Radhagupta played a very important role in Ashoka's rise. The Ashokavadana recounts Radhagupta offering Ashoka an old royal elephant for him to ride to the Garden of the Gold Pavilion where King Bindusara would determine his successor. Afterwards Ashoka got rid of the legitimate heir to the throne by tricking him into entering a pit full of live coals. According to the Ashokavadana Radhagupta would be appointed prime minister by Ashoka once he secured the throne - four years after his succession Ashoka was coronated in 269 BC.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Buddhist texts suggest that Ashoka was of a terrible nature and a bad temper - however Professor Charles Derekmeier cautions that these texts intend to dramatize the change that the religion brought to him, and thus exaggerate Ashoka's past after his conversion. What is known is that as Ashoka ascended the throne he expanded the empire over the next eight years - up to the present-day borders of Burma and Bangladesh, and the state of Assam in India in the east to present-day Iran, Persia and Afghanistan in the west. From the Pamir Knots in the north to very nearly the tip of the peninsula at southern India.
Kalinga - the Battle that Changed Everything

Of Ashoka's conquests as emperor of the Mauryan empire the Kalinga War is his most famous victory, but not from the tactics of the battle nor the valor of the men. During his reign Kalinga was a state that prided its sovereignty and democracy. As a monarchical parliamentary democracy the state was unique in ancient Bharata - the state adopted 'Rajdharma', meaning 'the duty of the rulers', which was entwined with bravery and dharma. Ashoka invaded the state and annexed it with relative ease, but as he cavorted the streets, basking in his victory, he was moved by the sheer number of bodies littering the ground - over 100,000 men fell in battle; 10,000 of which were Ashoka's own men, as well as a number of civilians rallying to defend Kalinga - and the wails of the kith and kin of the dead - the battle displaced more than 150,000 citizens.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]So touched and remorseful was Ashoka that he converted to Buddhism, rejecting violence and conquest and replacing it with peace and harmony. This ultimately led to massive expansion of the religion by Ashoka in the Mauryan empire and beyond at about c. 250 BC. His son and daughter - Mahinda and Sanghamitra respectively - later continued his expansion of Buddhism by establishing it in Ceylon, what is now Sri Lanka.

After the annexation of Kalinga and his conversation to Buddhism, Ashoka returned to his throne and ensured peace and friendly relations through the rest of his rule. Forty years past, and in that time Ashoka established a golden age in the empire.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Ashoka believed that Buddhism is beneficial for all man and animal-kind as well as the plant life, this belief encouraged the construction of many stupas, viharas, chaitya and other residences for Buddhist monks across the empire - according to the Ashokavadana he ordered the creation of 84,000 stupas to hold the Buddha's relics. He gave donations to viharas and mathas, sent his son and daughter to Sri Lanka to spread the religion, and also sent prominent Buddhist monks to present-day Kashmir, Afghanistan, Syria, Persia, Egypt, Greece, Italy, Turkey, Nepal, Bhutan, China, Mongolia, Cambodia, Laos, Burma, Thailand and Vietnam - Ashoka single-handedly spread Buddhism to all of the known world. Ashoka is also well known to have sent emissaries to transmit messages or letters to various people in the wider world. It was not unusual to add oral messages to the letters and these were used to spread his dhammavijaya - his victory through dhrama, which he saw as his greatest victory. Greeks living in the empire were also active in spreading Buddhism - some of Ashoka's emissaries are described in Pali sources as leading Greek Buddhist monks.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Domestically Ashoka held strong might until his conversion where he maintained friendlier ties with the frontier kingdoms. His edicts tell us that he provided medical treatment for humans and animals in and out of the empire, and built wells and planted trees along the roads to benefit his people. Ashoka banned the slaughter and consumption of cattle and imposed restriction on fishing and eating fish. By banning hunting, creative veterinary clinics and removed eating meat on many holidays the Mauryan Empire under Ashoka is described as "one of the few instances in world history of a government treating its animals as citizens who are as deserving of its protection as the human residents."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Ashokmudra, the Lion Capital of Ashoka is a sculpture of four Indian lions standing back to back. Originally it rested atop the Aśoka pillar in Sarnath, while the pillar still stands in its original location the Lion Capital is now in the Sarnath Museum. The Lion Capital has been adopted as the Indian national emblem and the "Ashoka Chakra", a Buddhist motif found at the Lion Capital's base, was adopted into the Indian flag in its center. Carved from a single block of polished sandstone, the capital contains the four lions mounted on an abacus, with a frieze carrying sculptures of an elephant, a horse, a bull and a lion by istelf, all separated by spoked chariot wheels over a bell-shaped lotus. The animals represent the different steps of Buddha's life; the elephant symbolizes Buddha's idea, referring to the dream of Queen Maya of a white elephant entering her womb. The bull represents desire during his life as a prince. The horse displays Buddha's departure from life in the palace. The lion represents his accomplishments. Other construction efforts from Ashoka include the Mahabodhi Temple in Bihar, Bhir Mound in Taxila and Butkara Stupa in Swat.

At the age of 72 Ashoka died in 232 BC. Legend says his body burned for seven days and nights during his cremation, however we know that his ashes were spread across the Ganges River possibly as Varanasi less than a day after his death. The reign of Ashoka was very nearly lost to the world, he left no record of his reign apart from the sculpted pillars found all around what was the empire. The pillars inscribed his actions and teachings he wanted to publish under his name, as a result of this Ashoka left behind the Prakrit language, the first written language in the subcontinent since the ancient Harappa. Just ten of the Ashokstambha - Pillars of Ashoka - survive with inscriptions. The first Ashokstambha was found in the 16th century by English traveler Thomas Coryat in the ruins of ancient Delhi.

Ashoka was without doubt one of the greatest leaders in Indian history, originally a mighty warrior and tactician Ashoka is more well known for his dramatic and iconic turnaround from an aggressor to a pacifist. His far-reaching spread of Buddhism and friendly banter to other kingdoms held the happiness of the people and kept the peace of the empire. One of Ashoka's most endearing legacies, Buddhist kingship is still present today in Thailand through the traditional role of the Thai king as a religious and secular leader.
